references.A44GRI01USGP: Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.
references.A75BAR01USGP: Barclay, H. J., and A. T. Bergerud. 1975. Demography and behavioral ecology of Califor-nia quail on Vancouver Island. Condor 77:315- 323.
references.A39EML01USGP: Emlen, John T. Jr. 1939. Seasonal movements of a low-density valley quail population. Journal of Wildlife Management, 3(2):118-130.
references.B73JOH01USGP: Johnsgard, P. A. 1973. Grouse and quails of North America. Univ. of Nebraska Press, Lincoln, NE.
references.A64MCM01USGP: McMillan, I. I. 1964. Annual population changes in California Quail. J. Wildl. Manage. 28: 702-711.
references.R45EML01USGP: Emlen, J. T., Jr., and Glading, B. 1945. Increasing valley quail in California.University of California Agricultural Experiment Station bulletin 695.
references.A92KIL01USGP: Killbride, K.M., J.A. Crawford, K.L. Blakely, and B.A. Williams. 1992. Habitat use by breeding female California quail in western Oregon. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 56(1):85-90.
references.A86STI01USGP: Stinnett, D.P. and D.A. Klebenow. 1986. Habitat use of irrigated lands by California quail in Nevada. The Journal of Wildlife Management, 50(3):368-372.

references.A91GOR01USGP: Gorenzel, W.P., S.A. Mastrup, and E.L. Fitzhugh. 1991. Economic relationships of brushpiles, forage production, and California quail hunting. Journal of Range Management, 44(2):129-133.
references.O99CAL01USGP: Calkins, Jennifer D., Julie C. Hagelin and Dale F. Lott. 1999. California Quail (Callipepla californica), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/473

habitat_description:
California quail is typically found where brush is interspersed with open areas (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Emlen and Glading, 1945; Johnsgaard, 1973). Foraging takes place in open, grassy areas (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Gorenzel et al., 1991) or in cultivated cropland (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Johnsgaard, 1973; Crawford, 1978; Stinnett and Klebenow, 1986), typically within 16 m of cover (Gutierrez, 1980; Gorenzel et al., 1991). Shrubs and trees are used for roosting and loafing (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Genelly, 1955; Leopold, 1977). Composition is less important than structure (Johnsgaard, 1973).

Specific habitats in which the species has been documented include: riparian woodlands and shrublands of willow and cottonwood (Emlen, 1939; Anthony, 1970; Stinnett and Klebenow, 1986); chaparral, including coastal, montane, and xeric (Johnsgaard, 1973; Leopold, 1977; Gutierrez, 1980; Calkins et al., 1999); coastal scrub (Calkins et al., 1999); oak woodlands and savanna (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Genelly, 1955; McMillan, 1964); pinyon and juniper steppe and woodlands (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Leopold, 1977); sagebrush steppe (Emlen and Glading, 1945; Leopold, 1977; Stinnett and Klebenow, 1986); forest openings created by logging or fire (Johnsgaard, 1973; Leopold, 1977); and abandoned, overgrown cropland (Stinnett and Klebenow, 1986).

In proximity to such shrub/grass habitats, California quail are known to inhabit the edges of: a Monterey pine plantation (Genelly, 1955); coastal redwood forest (Leopold, 1977); and mixed conifer forest (Gutierrez, 1980).

The species avoids dense forests and even thick shrubs (Johnsgaard, 1973) as well as sites devoid of herbaceous cover (Leopold, 1977). Extensive grazing that inhibits shrub growth also reduces populations of California quail (Leopold, 1977).

C. californica have been documented at elevations as high as 2590 m (Calkins et al., 1999).

Another constraint on the species is distance to water. Leopold (1977) states that California quail require open water on a daily basis. He also asserts that they have a daily movement radius of 800-1200 m.
